sn2.18:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa in the deer part at the Añjana Wood.
sn2.18:4.3: Then, late at night, the beautiful god Kakudha, lighting up the entire Añjana Wood, went up to the Buddha,
sn2.18:4.10: “Well then, ascetic, do you neither delight nor sorrow?”
sn2.18:5.2: I hope that delight isn’t found in you.
sn2.18:5.4: overwhelm you as you sit alone.”
sn2.18:6.2: and no delight is found in me.
sn2.18:6.4: overwhelm me as I sit alone.”
sn2.18:7.2: How is delight not found in you?
sn2.18:7.4: overwhelm you as you sit alone?”
sn2.18:8.3: Sir, you should know me as
sn2.18:8.4: a mendicant free of delight and misery.”
sn2.18:9.3: A mendicant free of delight and misery,
sn2.18:9.4: he’s crossed over clinging to the world.”
